content.title: Substrate Selection for Mourning Geckos
content.content: While mourning geckos are arboreal and spend most of their time climbing, substrate plays a critical role in maintaining the 60-80% humidity they require. Substrate also provides cushioning for occasional falls and supports bioactive systems with cleanup crews. Choosing the right substrate ensures proper moisture retention while preventing mold and bacterial growth.

In their native tropical rainforests, mourning geckos live among leaf litter on tree branches, rarely touching the forest floor. However, the forest floor provides constant moisture through decomposing organic matter and retains humidity throughout the day. In captivity, substrate replicates this moist, organic-rich environment even though the geckos primarily use vertical space.

Key requirement: Moisture-retentive substrate 2-4 inches deep that maintains humidity without becoming waterlogged. Should support microfauna for bioactive setups and enable natural foraging behaviors if cleanup crew is present.

For comprehensive guidance on substrate categories, DIY mixing formulas, impaction myths, and bioactive layering applicable to most reptiles, see our Substrate Selection Guide. The information below covers mourning gecko-specific substrate requirements and tropical habitat recommendations.
Several commercial products work well for mourning geckos. Look for tropical mixes designed for high-humidity species.

content.content: Creating your own tropical substrate is cost-effective and allows customization for bioactive setups. This formula provides excellent moisture retention and supports both plants and cleanup crews.

content.content: Mixing Instructions: Combine dry ingredients thoroughly in a large bin. Slowly add dechlorinated water while mixing until substrate reaches a consistency where it clumps when squeezed but doesn't drip. Allow to sit 24 hours before adding to enclosure. If using for bioactive, let cure for 2-4 weeks with cleanup crew before adding geckos.
Mourning geckos are insectivores/omnivores that hunt on vertical surfaces, so accidental substrate ingestion is extremely rare. However, proper husbandry prevents any potential issues.

content.text: Safety Best Practices:

rows: Geckos rarely descend to ground for food
Spot clean waste daily, add cleanup crew
Use organic topsoil, avoid Miracle-Gro or fertilizers

content.content: Unlike terrestrial species, substrate impaction is virtually non-existent in mourning geckos due to their arboreal lifestyle. Focus on humidity management and cleanliness instead.

Bioactive systems are ideal for mourning gecko colonies because cleanup crews handle waste management, reducing maintenance dramatically. This is especially beneficial as your colony grows through parthenogenesis.

rows: Prevents root rot, water overflow management
DIY tropical mix or Terra Fauna
Plant roots, cleanup crew habitat, humidity

content.content: Cleanup Crew Selection: Tropical species thrive at mourning gecko temperatures (70-85°F) and humidity (60-80%). Best options: Dwarf white isopods, powder blue isopods, dwarf purple isopods, and tropical springtails. Start with 20-30 isopods and 50+ springtails for a 12°12°18 enclosure.
Bioactive benefit: Cleanup crew processes waste, controls mold, and aerates substrate. Perfect for breeding colonies where population management is ongoing!
Substrate depth affects humidity retention and fall cushioning. Deeper substrate provides better moisture buffering and supports bioactive microfauna populations.
A generous leaf litter layer is ESSENTIAL for both bioactive and non-bioactive setups. It provides hiding spots for cleanup crews, retains moisture, and creates a naturalistic appearance.

content.text: Leaf Litter Options:

content.content: Never collect leaves from roadsides or areas treated with pesticides. If collecting wild leaves, bake at 200°F for 30 minutes to sterilize, or purchase commercial reptile-safe leaf litter.
Substrate maintenance depends on whether you use bioactive or non-bioactive systems.

content.text: Maintenance Schedule:

content.content: Proper substrate moisture is critical for humidity maintenance without creating swampy conditions.

content.text: Moisture Testing:

rows: Too dry: mist substrate. Too wet: increase ventilation
Substrate appears damp but not muddy
Light fog on glass mornings, clears by afternoon
Too much: reduce misting. Too little: mist more

content.content: Pro tip: Mist substrate edges and leaf litter rather than soaking the entire substrate. This creates humid microclimates while allowing drier areas for cleanup crew egg laying.
Some substrates are inappropriate for mourning geckos due to humidity, safety, or practicality issues.

content.text: Incompatible Substrates:

rows: Traps bacteria, impossible to clean with waste accumulation
Insufficient moisture retention, inappropriate for tropical species
Toxic aromatic oils, wrong habitat type
Zero humidity retention, no fall cushioning

content.content: Mourning geckos are tropical rainforest species - desert substrates (sand, calcium sand) or arid setups will cause dehydration and respiratory issues. Always prioritize moisture retention.
